name: KestrelDock Autonomy
description: Builds autonomous tug assist systems and port-side sensor networks to reduce docking incidents and fuel use.
culture: Safety-first and procedural; decisions are documented. Slack is used for quick coordination but expects clear timestamps, vessel IDs, and escalation paths. Tone is direct, low-emotion, and detail-oriented.
location_context: Rotterdam, Netherlands; hybrid (engineering in-office 3 days, ops partially remote)

people.name: Marieke van Houten
people.personality: Methodical and calm under pressure; keeps personal feelings out of work threads. Prefers resolving ambiguity early and will pause projects to clarify requirements. Can be impatient with speculative discussions.
people.communication_style: Writes concise, structured Slack updates with bullet points and exact references (dock number, timestamp). Non-native English phrasing can be literal; avoids emojis and uses formal greetings in cross-team channels.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Formal Tone in Fast Channels
coaching_flags.description: Messages read like emails, slowing back-and-forth and making collaboration feel rigid.

coaching_flags.name: Directive Language Without Softening
coaching_flags.description: Uses imperative phrasing that can sound like an order rather than a request in mixed-seniority rooms.

coaching_flags.name: Assumes Shared Context
coaching_flags.description: References systems or incident numbers without a short summary for teammates outside her domain.

coaching_flags.name: Sparse Acknowledgements
coaching_flags.description: Rarely confirms receipt or thanks, which can reduce clarity about ownership and status.

people.flag_rationale: As an integration lead coordinating ops, engineering, and vendors, her direct and formal style helps precision but can read as abrupt. Adding lightweight context and confirmation improves cross-functional alignment without sacrificing safety rigor.

people.name: Sanjay Raghavan Iyer
people.personality: Highly focused and proud of clean technical solutions; prefers deep work blocks and answers when certain. Tends to over-explain technical reasoning when challenged. Avoids conflict but can become defensive if his work is questioned.
people.communication_style: Writes long messages with nested parentheses and technical acronyms; occasional Indian English phrasing (e.g., "kindly revert", "do the needful"). Uses minimal emojis and replies in-thread, sometimes too late after thinking.

coaching_flags.name: Wall of Text Without Structure
coaching_flags.description: Long explanations lack headings or a summary, making it hard to find the decision or next step.

coaching_flags.name: Excessive Jargon for Mixed Audiences
coaching_flags.description: Uses firmware/control-system terms without translating impact for ops or product stakeholders.

coaching_flags.name: Delayed Response Without Status
coaching_flags.description: Goes quiet while investigating; others interpret silence as lack of progress or ownership.

coaching_flags.name: Defensive Framing
coaching_flags.description: Replies that justify decisions can come across as resisting feedback instead of collaborating.

people.flag_rationale: As a contractor interfacing with non-engineers, he needs to summarize first, then detail. Quick status pings and less defensive wording will reduce churn during incident response windows.

name: Cedar & Coil Atelier
type: Luxury audio product design studio (creative manufacturing)
description: Designs boutique tube amplifiers and hand-finished speakers for small-run releases and gallery installations.
culture: In-office and tactile; decisions happen near prototypes, and Slack is used to capture approvals, vendor updates, and mood boards. Communication is expressive but expects clear sign-offs to keep builds moving.
location_context: Osaka, Japan; in-office (design/build), limited remote for admin

people.name: Aiko Nishimura
people.personality: Observant and detail-driven; notices tiny inconsistencies and cares about craft. Avoids blunt disagreement and prefers proposing alternatives. Gets anxious when decisions are left open-ended.
people.communication_style: Polite, indirect English with honorific-like softness ("maybe we can consider..."). Uses a few tasteful emojis (✨, 🙇) and attaches reference images; sometimes avoids saying "no" explicitly.

coaching_flags.name: Overuse of Hedging Language
coaching_flags.description: Excessive softeners (maybe, perhaps) obscure her actual recommendation and urgency.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Decision Requests
coaching_flags.description: Shares options but doesn’t specify what approval is needed and by when.

coaching_flags.name: Avoids Explicit Disagreement
coaching_flags.description: Skips stating constraints directly, leading others to assume feasibility.

coaching_flags.name: Attachment-Only Context
coaching_flags.description: Relies on images without summarizing the key comparison points in text.

people.flag_rationale: In a craft studio, her sensitivity is valuable, but decisions stall when her preference isn’t explicit. Clear asks and firmer recommendations help production timelines without compromising politeness.

people.name: Mateo Álvares Siqueira
people.personality: Friendly and pragmatic; keeps relationships warm with vendors and teammates. Juggles multiple commitments and can forget to close loops. Prefers quick wins over perfect documentation.
people.communication_style: Casual tone with lots of short messages; uses emojis (👍😅) and Portuguese-influenced word order. Sometimes mixes Portuguese terms for parts/vendors and assumes others know them.

coaching_flags.name: Missing Context in Requests
coaching_flags.description: Asks for info or approvals without specifying which project, SKU, or deadline.

coaching_flags.name: Fragmented Messaging
coaching_flags.description: Sends many short pings that scatter details across a channel.

coaching_flags.name: Terminology Mixing
coaching_flags.description: Switches between Portuguese and English labels for the same item, causing confusion.

coaching_flags.name: Loose Commitments
coaching_flags.description: Uses vague promises ("I’ll check") without a concrete time for follow-up.

people.flag_rationale: Because he’s part-time and manages vendor coordination, clarity and consolidation are essential. Better structured requests and consistent naming prevent expensive ordering mistakes.

name: Nivalis Reinsurance Group
description: Underwrites catastrophe reinsurance and builds internal models for climate-linked portfolio exposure.
culture: High-formality and audit-aware; Slack is used but messages are expected to be precise, compliant, and non-speculative. Pace spikes during renewal seasons; channel etiquette is strict about confidentiality.
location_context: Zürich, Switzerland; hybrid (2 days remote, regulated data on secure VDI)

people.name: Claudine Berset
people.personality: Decisive and organized; values clarity and accountability. Prefers fewer meetings and expects preparation. Can come off cold when stressed by deadlines.
people.communication_style: Formal, crisp English with French punctuation habits (spaces before : ;). Rarely uses emojis; often writes in complete sentences and expects confirmation of action items.

coaching_flags.name: Abrupt Closings
coaching_flags.description: Ends threads quickly without relational cues, which can feel dismissive to junior staff.

coaching_flags.name: High-Stakes Language
coaching_flags.description: Uses risk-heavy wording ("unacceptable", "must") that may escalate tension unnecessarily.

coaching_flags.name: Thread Hijacking
coaching_flags.description: Redirects discussions to new topics without creating a new thread/channel, reducing traceability.

coaching_flags.name: Limited Psychological Safety Signals
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t invite questions, so teammates may hide uncertainty until late.

people.flag_rationale: As a director, her precision is an asset, but junior analysts need clearer permission to ask and clarify. Small tone adjustments can improve escalation quality without reducing rigor.

people.name: Tobias Kwon
people.personality: Thoughtful and curious; double-checks work and prefers to be accurate over fast. Hesitates to speak up in large channels. Enjoys solving puzzles and can hyperfocus.
people.communication_style: Terse messages with minimal small talk; asks questions in a cautious way. Occasionally uses German sentence structure in English and may omit articles; rarely uses emojis.

coaching_flags.name: Under-Communicating Progress
coaching_flags.description: Provides results only at the end, not intermediate checkpoints, risking misalignment.

coaching_flags.name: Question Framing Too Tentative
coaching_flags.description: Asks in a way that hides what he already tried, making it harder for others to help.

coaching_flags.name: Ambiguous Ownership
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t clearly state what he will do next vs. what he needs from others.

coaching_flags.name: Grammar: Articles & Word Order
coaching_flags.description: German-influenced English can reduce clarity in technical summaries.

people.flag_rationale: As a new analyst, he benefits from frequent alignment and clearer asks. Improving question framing and ownership statements will speed feedback loops and reduce rework.

name: Harborview Community Health Network
description: Operates a network of community clinics and a care coordination team for chronic disease management.
culture: Patient-centered and collaborative; Slack supports shift handoffs and coordination but avoids PHI. Tone is warm, and clarity is vital during high-volume clinic days.
location_context: Ontario, Canada; hybrid (clinical in-person, admin/care coordinators remote 2-3 days)

people.name: Nkechi Okafor-Mills
people.personality: Empathetic and firm; keeps the team grounded when caseloads spike. Has a strong sense of fairness and notices when workload distribution slips. Can move quickly and expects others to keep up.
people.communication_style: Direct and encouraging; uses short checklists and occasional emojis (✅). Sometimes writes urgent messages without enough routing details when juggling multiple patient flows (without PHI).

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Action Items Under Time Pressure
coaching_flags.description: Urgent posts lack who/when, leading to duplicated effort.

coaching_flags.name: Broadcasting Instead of Targeting
coaching_flags.description: Uses broad channels for items that should be assigned to specific roles.

coaching_flags.name: Inconsistent Use of Templates
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t always follow the team’s handoff format, reducing reliability.

coaching_flags.name: Tone Swings During Surges
coaching_flags.description: Can sound clipped when stressed, which may feel harsh to frontline staff.

people.flag_rationale: She coordinates many moving parts; better targeting and consistent templates will reduce confusion, and tone consistency will protect team morale during surges.

people.name: Jinwoo Park
people.personality: Quietly dependable; prefers clear instructions and is eager to be useful. Avoids interrupting and may take on too much without flagging capacity. Learns fast when given examples.
people.communication_style: Very polite English; may use honorific-like phrasing ("Could you please..."). Writes minimal messages and sometimes omits critical details because he assumes they’re obvious; almost no emojis.

coaching_flags.name: Missing Operational Details
coaching_flags.description: Requests/updates omit time, clinic location, or which workflow step is complete.

coaching_flags.name: Reluctance to Escalate
coaching_flags.description: Hesitates to flag blockers or capacity issues, risking patient flow delays.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Apologizing
coaching_flags.description: Frequent apologies reduce confidence and can obscure the actual issue.

coaching_flags.name: Low Visibility Participation
coaching_flags.description: Rarely posts status, so supervisors can’t proactively reassign tasks.

people.flag_rationale: As a float MA, small missing details cascade into scheduling and rooming delays. Coaching helps him provide complete updates and escalate early without feeling impolite.

name: SaffronGrid Microfoods
description: Produces fermented bases and ready-to-cook components for restaurant groups and specialty grocers.
culture: Operations-heavy and metrics-driven; Slack is used for line changeovers, QA exceptions, and maintenance tickets. Communication is blunt but should remain respectful; photos and batch numbers are standard.
location_context: Pune, India; in-office for plant teams, limited remote for planning/finance

people.name: Rupali Deshmukh
people.personality: Principled and vigilant; treats standards as non-negotiable. Prefers evidence over opinions and keeps meticulous logs. Can become terse when she feels safety is being compromised.
people.communication_style: Short, authoritative messages with batch IDs and pass/fail statements. Uses Indian English formality ("Please ensure") and rarely uses emojis; may sound accusatory when pointing out deviations.

coaching_flags.name: Blame-Forward Wording
coaching_flags.description: Findings are phrased like personal fault instead of process deviation, triggering defensiveness.

coaching_flags.name: Insufficient Explanation of Impact
coaching_flags.description: States rejection without a brief risk rationale, reducing buy-in from production.

coaching_flags.name: Escalation Without Heads-Up
coaching_flags.description: Jumps to leadership tags before attempting a quick clarification with the line lead.

coaching_flags.name: Overuse of Compliance Boilerplate
coaching_flags.description: Repeats standard policy text rather than tailoring the actionable steps.

people.flag_rationale: QA authority is essential, but production cooperation improves when findings are framed as shared process fixes with impact and next steps. Better escalation sequencing reduces friction.

people.name: Hassan Al-Masri
people.personality: Hands-on problem solver; enjoys diagnosing unusual mechanical failures. Works nights and can feel out of sync with day teams. Prefers clear priorities and dislikes lengthy debates.
people.communication_style: Very terse, sometimes missing vowels/grammar in English; uses voice notes and photos more than text. Can sound abrupt; occasionally uses Arabic transliteration for parts he learned on previous jobs.

coaching_flags.name: Incomplete Ticket Updates
coaching_flags.description: Posts fixes without documenting root cause, downtime, or next preventive step.

coaching_flags.name: Terse Tone Misread as Rude
coaching_flags.description: Short replies lack politeness markers, causing interpersonal friction.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Priority Confirmation
coaching_flags.description: Starts work without restating which issue he’s tackling first, risking misalignment.

coaching_flags.name: Language Clarity: Missing Articles & Verb Tense
coaching_flags.description: Errors can obscure whether something is done, in progress, or blocked.

people.flag_rationale: Night shift relies on written handoffs. More complete updates and clearer status language prevent repeat failures and reduce day-team confusion.

name: Verdant Vale Retail Co-op
description: Member-owned grocery stores focusing on local sourcing, fair-trade products, and community programs.
culture: Community-minded and consensus-oriented; Slack is used across stores for promotions, staffing gaps, and vendor issues. Friendly tone is the norm, but decisions can drift without clear owners.
location_context: Auckland, New Zealand; hybrid (HQ roles remote 2 days, stores in-person)

people.name: Talia Ngata
people.personality: Energetic and people-focused; likes to keep everyone informed. Moves fast and multitasks across stores. Can get frustrated when others don’t respond quickly.
people.communication_style: Chatty and upbeat; uses emojis frequently and tags many people. Sometimes mixes multiple topics in one message and assumes others will infer the plan.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Tagging and Notification Fatigue
coaching_flags.description: Tags broad groups for items that only need a couple of owners, reducing responsiveness.

coaching_flags.name: Multi-Topic Messages
coaching_flags.description: Combines staffing, promo, and vendor issues in one post, making tasks easy to miss.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Escalation Criteria
coaching_flags.description: Escalates urgent-sounding items without defining what makes them urgent.

coaching_flags.name: Assumed Consensus
coaching_flags.description: Uses inclusive language ("we’ll do") without confirming agreement or owner.

people.flag_rationale: Her inclusivity supports co-op culture, but clearer ownership and fewer tags will make store coordination smoother and reduce missed tasks.

people.name: Oleg Sokolov
people.personality: Analytical and earnest; wants to contribute value quickly. Prefers working independently and can over-rely on dashboards. Feels awkward asking “obvious” questions and may wait too long.
people.communication_style: Formal English with Slavic phrasing; tends to paste raw tables or screenshots. Uses no emojis and can sound stiff; may not summarize insights upfront.

coaching_flags.name: Data Dump Without Narrative
coaching_flags.description: Shares outputs without explaining what it means or what decision it supports.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Audience Targeting
coaching_flags.description: Posts analytic details in operational channels instead of tailoring to store leads.

coaching_flags.name: Hesitant Clarification Requests
coaching_flags.description: Avoids asking questions early, leading to analysis on the wrong metric.

coaching_flags.name: Formatting: Tables Not Readable in Slack
coaching_flags.description: Pastes wide tables that break on mobile and obscure key numbers.

people.flag_rationale: As an intern, he’ll be judged on usefulness, not volume of data. Coaching helps him lead with insights, tailor to the audience, and ask alignment questions sooner.

name: LexRiver Chambers
description: Advises employers and unions on workplace disputes, investigations, and compliance training.
culture: High precision and confidentiality; Slack is used internally for scheduling, research tasks, and drafting coordination. Tone is professional; responses should be clear, with careful wording and minimal speculation.
location_context: London, UK; hybrid (client meetings in-office, drafting often remote)

people.name: Priya Malhotra-Singh
people.personality: Detail-obsessed and conscientious; likes to be certain before committing. Tries to be helpful and sometimes takes on too much. Can get anxious when instructions are vague.
people.communication_style: Writes careful, clause-like Slack messages with caveats. Rarely uses emojis; tends to ask multiple clarifying questions in one go and mirrors legal phrasing even in casual channels.

coaching_flags.name: Excessive Hedging and Caveats
coaching_flags.description: Over-qualifies statements, making it hard to identify the recommendation.

coaching_flags.name: Question Overload
coaching_flags.description: Bundles many questions without prioritizing, overwhelming the recipient.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Formal Register
coaching_flags.description: Uses legalistic language where a simple internal note would be clearer.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Task Acceptance
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t explicitly confirm what she will deliver and by when.

people.flag_rationale: Legal precision is necessary, but internal Slack needs faster clarity. Reducing caveats and confirming deliverables improves turnaround without increasing risk.

people.name: Gareth Llewelyn Price
people.personality: Efficient and protective of his time; likes repeatable systems. Can be skeptical of last-minute requests and prefers clear priorities. Dry humor that doesn’t always land in text.
people.communication_style: Very terse, often single-line replies; uses minimal punctuation and occasional sarcasm. Avoids emojis; may respond with “seen” or “noted” without confirming action.

coaching_flags.name: Ambiguous Acknowledgements
coaching_flags.description: Replies like “noted” don’t clarify whether he will act or just read.

coaching_flags.name: Dry Humor Risk
coaching_flags.description: Sarcastic phrasing can be misinterpreted as dismissive or hostile.

coaching_flags.name: Gatekeeping Tone
coaching_flags.description: Pushback is phrased as refusal rather than offering alternatives or trade-offs.

coaching_flags.name: Lack of Deadline Signposting
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t communicate when he can complete a task, causing planning issues.

people.flag_rationale: As the operational backbone, his clarity sets the firm’s pace. Small adjustments—explicit ownership, alternatives, and deadline cues—reduce friction and misreads.

name: Makueni Water Futures Programme
type: NGO focused on rural water access & climate resilience
description: Partners with county offices and communities to maintain boreholes, train water committees, and run drought preparedness projects.
culture: Mission-driven and relationship-focused; Slack bridges field teams and donors. Communication is respectful and narrative-heavy, but needs crisp reporting for accountability.
location_context: Makueni County, Kenya; remote-first with frequent field travel (low bandwidth considerations)

people.name: Wanjiku Ndirangu
people.personality: Resourceful and grounded; good at calming tense community meetings. Prefers practical steps over theory. Can become overwhelmed by donor reporting requirements.
people.communication_style: Warm and story-oriented English; sometimes uses Swahili terms for community roles and local concepts. Sends updates as long paragraphs from her phone; uses a few emojis sparingly.

coaching_flags.name: Narrative Updates Without Metrics
coaching_flags.description: Shares stories but omits key numbers (sites visited, parts replaced, costs).

coaching_flags.name: Wall of Text from Mobile
coaching_flags.description: Long paragraphs lack headings, making it hard to scan.

coaching_flags.name: Untranslated Local Terms
coaching_flags.description: Uses Swahili/community titles without brief explanations for donor-facing staff.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Ask vs. FYI
coaching_flags.description: Updates don’t clearly state whether she needs approval, funds, or just awareness.

people.flag_rationale: Her field insight is valuable, but HQ needs structured, metric-linked updates for funding and logistics. Clear asks and scannable formats improve support for her work.

people.name: Eduardo Valdés Ríos
people.personality: Curious and systematic; enjoys building indicators and cleaning messy datasets. Can be blunt about data quality and gets impatient when definitions change. Prefers asynchronous work.
people.communication_style: Writes medium-long English messages with Spanish-influenced phrasing and false friends ("actual" meaning current). Uses parentheses and quick corrections; low emoji use; can sound critical when requesting clarifications.

coaching_flags.name: Data Quality Feedback Too Harsh
coaching_flags.description: Points out issues in ways that feel personal rather than process-focused.

coaching_flags.name: False Friends and Ambiguity
coaching_flags.description: Spanish-influenced word choices can change meaning in reports and requests.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Indexing on Definitions
coaching_flags.description: Spends too much message space debating terminology instead of proposing a practical next step.

coaching_flags.name: Assumes Statistical Literacy
coaching_flags.description: Uses evaluation jargon without explaining implications for field actions.

people.flag_rationale: He supports teams with varying data comfort. Softer framing and clearer, action-oriented explanations will improve collaboration and adoption of M&E practices.

name: HelioStack Grid Services
type: Utility-scale renewable energy operations (solar + battery O&M)
description: Runs operations and maintenance for solar farms and battery sites, including SCADA monitoring and dispatch coordination.
culture: Incident-driven and time-sensitive; Slack is the live ops console with strict runbooks. Messages must be short, unambiguous, and tagged with site codes; formality is moderate but efficiency rules.
location_context: Texas, USA; remote-first for NOC, in-office for field crews

people.name: Keisha Burnett
people.personality: Steady and decisive; excels at triage and keeping calm during alarms. Expects crisp execution and dislikes rambling. Can become overly controlling when multiple incidents overlap.
people.communication_style: Very concise commands and checklists; uses all-caps sparingly for urgency and little to no emojis. May skip pleasantries and push for immediate confirmations.

coaching_flags.name: Command-Heavy Tone
coaching_flags.description: Directive phrasing can reduce collaboration and discourage proactive suggestions.

coaching_flags.name: All-Caps/Alarm Language Overuse
coaching_flags.description: Frequent urgency signals create stress and make true escalations harder to spot.

coaching_flags.name: Insufficient Context for New Staff
coaching_flags.description: Assumes everyone knows the runbook step she’s referencing.

coaching_flags.name: Single-Thread Bottlenecking
coaching_flags.description: Routes too many decisions through herself instead of delegating clearly.

people.flag_rationale: As shift lead, her clarity is crucial, but tone and delegation affect team performance over long shifts. Small adjustments can maintain urgency while improving psychological safety and throughput.

people.name: Yusuf Al-Harithi
people.personality: Curious and careful; prefers to verify before changing configurations. Respectful to authority and may hesitate to contradict. Enjoys documenting systems and creating diagrams.
people.communication_style: Polite, slightly formal English; may use indirect phrasing and longer greetings. Sometimes struggles with prepositions and tense; uses no emojis and avoids public disagreement in channels.

coaching_flags.name: Hesitation to Challenge Assumptions
coaching_flags.description: Avoids voicing concerns in-channel, which can delay incident correction.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Confidence Level
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t state whether he is certain or hypothesizing, confusing decision-making.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Formal Openers in Incident Threads
coaching_flags.description: Adds greetings that slow rapid-response communication.

coaching_flags.name: Grammar: Prepositions & Tense Clarity
coaching_flags.description: Small errors can change meaning in operational status updates.

people.flag_rationale: In grid ops, timely, clear, and appropriately assertive communication is safety-critical. Coaching helps him signal certainty, raise concerns earlier, and streamline incident-thread wording.

name: Northbridge Polytechnic Registrar
description: Manages enrollment, transcripts, course scheduling coordination, and policy communications for a polytechnic institute.
culture: Process-oriented and service-focused; Slack is used for coordination across departments and for handling peaks during enrollment. Tone is courteous, but clarity and documentation matter for policy compliance.
location_context: Queensland, Australia; hybrid (front desk in-person, records team remote 2 days)

people.name: Brontë Caldwell
people.personality: Organized and student-advocate minded; tries to make policies understandable. Can get overloaded and then becomes overly process-heavy. Likes predictable routines and well-labeled files.
people.communication_style: Friendly but policy-forward; writes medium-length messages with links to forms. Uses occasional emojis in internal channels; may over-quote policy text instead of summarizing.

coaching_flags.name: Policy Copy-Paste Without Summary
coaching_flags.description: Shares large blocks of policy rather than a short plain-language takeaway.

coaching_flags.name: Over-Process in Simple Requests
coaching_flags.description: Adds unnecessary steps that slow routine coordination.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Prioritization During Peaks
coaching_flags.description: Doesn’t indicate which items are urgent vs. can wait, causing queue confusion.

coaching_flags.name: Link-Heavy Messages
coaching_flags.description: Relies on multiple links without stating exactly what the recipient should do.

people.flag_rationale: Her role demands compliance, but teammates need quick, actionable guidance. Summaries, priority markers, and clearer CTAs will reduce back-and-forth during enrollment surges.

people.name: Somchai Kittisak
people.personality: Patient and meticulous; enjoys making messy records consistent. Prefers clear written instructions and can be shy in group threads. Will quietly fix issues rather than announcing them.
people.communication_style: Short, polite English with Thai-influenced directness (sometimes omits subjects). Uses no emojis; may answer with minimal context like “Done” without specifying what changed.

coaching_flags.name: Minimal Status Updates
coaching_flags.description: Replies lack detail about what was completed, what remains, or where to verify.

coaching_flags.name: Under-Visibility of Proactive Fixes
coaching_flags.description: Fixes issues quietly, so teams don’t learn patterns or prevent repeats.

coaching_flags.name: Unclear Questions
coaching_flags.description: Asks for clarification without referencing the exact record/course code, causing delays.

coaching_flags.name: Politeness Over Precision
coaching_flags.description: Avoids stating constraints directly (e.g., can’t do due to policy), leading to re-asks.

people.flag_rationale: In records work, traceability matters. More descriptive updates and precise referencing will improve audit readiness and reduce repeated follow-ups from academic departments.
